div.head: Title
Genre
div.p: Narrative poem, rendering in verse scenes from The Monastery by Walter Scott.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS IA; MS III.

div.head: Date
div.p: A range of 1827–29 is possible. “Book I” and “Book II” may have been composed as early as 1827–28; “Book III” and “Book IV” may have been completed by March 1829.

W. G. Collingwood dated the work from the “early part of 1828” or “first half of 1828”. based on his analysis of the sequence in which Ruskin entered poetry selections in MS III (see Composition and Publication; and see Poems [4o, 1891], 1:262, 272; Poems [8o, 1891] 1:263, 273; Ruskin, Works, 2:530). E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn disagreed and ascribed the work to 1827, in the belief that the poem was "a result of [Ruskin's] visit to Scotland in that year" (Ruskin, Works 2:260 n. 1; and see 276 n. 1). Helen Viljoen was initially inclined to accept the earlier date, because she considered the hand in the IA draft to be "very childish", but then she decided that Cook and Wedderburn had "no legitimate basis" for correcting Collingwood's date of 1828 (“Helen Gill Viljoen Papers”, box F, transcription of “The Monastery”).

The reasoning by the editors of the Library Edition does seem to stand on the most speculative evidence, dependent solely on Ruskin's comment in Praeterita that he "used to read the Abbot at Kinross, and the Monastery in Glen Farg" (Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1; 35:16). While Ruskin may well have associated Walter Scott's novels with landmarks along the Ruskins' routes to Scotland in the 1820s, why should these associations be tied so specifically to the journey of 1827? It is not known when Ruskin first read Scott's Monastery or heard it read to him. That journey did result, however, in the writing that immediately precedes Ruskin's "Monastery" in MS III--the anthology, “poetry descriptive” (see also Tours of 1826–27). Whether "The Monastery"--or at least its first Book--should be considered a contemporaneous part of that 1827 poetry project, or, as Collingwood contends, an insertion in that place from a later time, the poem's juxtaposition with an anthology of poems describing Lochleven and Glen Farg, among other places, does appear to confirm the associations that Ruskin commemorated in Praeterita.

As explained in Composition and Publication, the only documented record of Ruskin's labor on “The Monastery” dates from March 1829, and even that passing reference in a letter is ambiguous. In the letter, Ruskin may refer to composition and/or fair copy of the poem itself, or he may simply be identifying MS III by its contents--the Red Book containing his versification, "The Monastery"--whereas his burst of activity on the notebook in March 1829 may not have included that poem at all. Based on the concatenation of evidence in Composition and Publication, however, it appears that Books I-II of the poem likely date from late 1827 or 1828, while Books III-IV--in fair copy, if not their composition--date from March 1829.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: In a 4 March 1829 letter to her husband, Margaret Ruskin referred to Johnʼs writing “a novel” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 185)—presumably, this versification of scenes from the first four chapters of Walter Scottʼs novel, The Monastery (1820). In a 10 March letter to his father, John confirmed: “I am trying to get that red book of mine which has the Monastery in it finished, by the time you come home” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 192). Of the surviving Red Books, only MS III contains this work.

In MS III, “The Monastery” immediately follows a group of poems entitled “poetry descriptive”, which Ruskin fair-copied no earlier than May 1827, and probably sometime between June 1827 and New Year's 1828 (see “Wales”: Date; and “poetry descriptive”: Date). Ruskin supplied no physical break between the anthology and the "novel" to indicate a change in genre or projects, so it is possible that he considered "The Monastery" as a continuation of the "poetry discriptive". However, the hand for the verse novel uses considerably smaller print lettering; and since Ruskin had taken up pen and ink for the first time in April 1827, only shortly before he could have begun compiling "poetry discriptive", it is reasonable to conjecture that the two projects were separated by some of amount of time, with the fair copy of the verse novel benefiting from Ruskin's increased practice with a pen (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). The neglect of a physical separation does not necessarily imply, moreover, that Ruskin misunderstood the difference between the brief lyric mode of descriptive verse and a long narrative poem: from the outset of the fair copy, he divided “The Monastery” into numbered "books" that corresponded to chapters in Scott's novel—a sequence that Ruskin could have extended to the end of the original story, but that he never carried beyond Scott's chapter four, so far as the record shows.

Ruskinʼs 10 March 1829 letter to his father implies that John James was already familiar with some portion of the versified novel, so the first book or books may have significantly predated his "finishing" MS III. In fact, Ruskin's promise "to get that red book of mine which has the Monastery in it finished" does not necessarily include a commitment to work on "The Monastery" itself, which is certainly not complete in any obvious sense. However, the physical disposition of the fair copy in MS III can be interpreted as reflecting two distinct stages of labor on the poem, with a break in time possibly occurring between books 1-2 and 3-4.

In MS III, books 1-2 run from the last poem fair-copied in "poetry discriptive" to almost the end of the notebook (pp. 70-80), concluding with a colophon, "END OF BOOK SECOND / HERNE HILL / DULWICH"; and then, with the direction "go back to page 52" inserted as part of the colophon, the poem resumes on page 52 with book 3, and extending through book 4, which seems uncompleted. The pages occupied by the latter two books (pp. 52-58, plus three blank pages, 59-61) take up the available leaves that fall between those containing a group of poems dated 9 March 1829 (pp. 36-50, plus the blank p. 51) and the leaves containing the “poetry descriptive” (pp. 62-70). In Ruskin's process of filling these interstitial leaves with books 3-4, the space occupied by "poetry discriptive" unquestionably presented a terminus ad quem of available space, while a terminus a quo was likely already present in the form of the March 9 poetry group. While the latter inference cannot be proven, since Ruskin could have decided arbitrarily to resume with book 3 on p. 52, with nothing in particular framing that space, the physical evidence does suggest that he composed and/or fair-copied at least books 3 and 4 of “The Monastery” at about the same time that he was filling a preceding set of pages with a group of poems that he prominently and repeatedly dated 9 March 1829. This frenzy of activity was meant to demonstrate, as he announced to his father on 10 March, that he would “get that red book of mine [MS III] which has the Monastery in it finished, by the time you come home”. (For the March 9 group, see its last-copied poem, “Of rocks first and of caverns now i sing”).

MS IA includes a one‐sheet, ink, longhand set of lines that forms part of the MS III poemʼs “book third”, as well as a one‐sheet pencil version of part of the MS III poemʼs “book second” (see part 2, MS IA, “Content”, a). It is possible that the MS IA pencil version of part of “book second” is earlier than 1829, since the fair copy of “book third” is the portion positioned following the March 9 group in the MS III, while “book second” runs continuously to the end of MS III. Even the MS IA ink version of part of “book third”, conceivably, could significantly predate its March 1829 fair‐copying.

The MS IA copies, then, do hold open the possibility of a starting date perhaps up to a year prior to the projectʼs termination in 1829. Moreover, given Ruskinʼs hectic pace of writing and fair‐copying for New Yearʼs 1828 and for his fatherʼs 1829 birthday (see nos. 32–33, 57 “Harry and Lucy”, Vol. III, “A Battle: Irregular Measure”, “Battle of Waterloo: A Play in Two Acts”), it seems barely credible that even Ruskin could have produced all of his “novel” during the same period. If these indications are sound, I believe the onset of composition is unlikely to have been much earlier than the middle of 1828, however, since the handwriting and punctuation in the first two books is reminiscent of “Eudosia” (no. 27).

Since the extant manuscript evidence places books 3–4 of the poem (or, at least, their fair‐copying) squarely in 1829, while only permitting an earlier date for books 1–2, the case for assigning an earlier date to some portion of the poem must depend on internal evidence—the events captured from Scottʼs novel, and the order in which Ruskin set them to verse. See Discussion: since book 1 lifts events out of their order in Scott, the poem could represent an earlier, isolated versification, which Ruskin only later in 1829 decided to develop—“commenc[ing] writing a novel”, as his mother said.
(so far, that is, as “The Monastery” ever did reach completion).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Ruskinʼs book 2 begins with the opening of Scottʼs chap. 3, the widowing of the Lady of Avenel and her removal with her daughter to the shepherdʼs cottage of Martin and Tibb Tacket; and book 2 then moves to Scottʼs chap. 2, the confrontation between Captain Stawarth Bolton and Dame Glendinning and her two sons of Glendearg.

Ruskinʼs book 3 versifies the remainder of Scottʼs chap. 3—Martin, Tibb, Mary, and the Lady of Avenelʼs journey to Dame Glendinningʼs residence in Glendearg (which Ruskin calls “Glenfarg” and “Glendarg” [see Ruskin, Works, 35:16]), and their attempted passage across a bog, when Mary and the pony Shagram see the White Lady signaling them to safety.
Ruskinʼs book 4 is from Scottʼs chap. 4, the apparition of her dead father to Mary Avenel on Halloween night.

That Ruskinʼs book 1 lifts events out of their sequential narrative order in Scott—therefore, possibly representing an earlier, isolated versification of Scottʼs chapter 5, which Ruskin decided only later in 1829 to develop—points to a fascination with Scottʼs fifth chapter that was deeply entrenched in Ruskinʼs childhood. Bridges had interested him since 1823, when his aunt presented him with the cherished model of Waterloo Bridge (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 127). The White Lady may have been associated in Ruskinʼs mind with Byronʼs “witch of the waters at the Alps” in no. 3, “Harry and Lucy”, Vol. 1 (1826–27), who occurs to Harry when he “observed a rainbow and a rising mist under it which his fancy soon transformed into a female form” (in book 3 of “The Monastery”, the White Lady is a “form appearing like a fog”). Of course, these associations could just as likely have traveled the other way, with witches and bridges leading to his later fascination with the perils of the White Lady in “The Monastery”.

If book 1 probes images that were profoundly arresting for Ruskin throughout his earlier years, books 2–4 are enriched by a possible connection with the death of Ruskinʼs Aunt Jessie of Perth and the Ruskinsʼ subsequent adoption of her daughter Mary (see nos. 25–26 Travel Itinerary and Tour Notes [1828], “The Sound of the Sea”). Cousin Mary came to Herne Hill in July 1828 (A Tour to the Lakes in Cumberland, 7), an event that might well have put Ruskin in mind of the two families joining in “The Monastery”—the widowed Lady Avenel and her daughter Mary with the widowed Dame Glendinning and her two sons. In this light, the end of Ruskinʼs poem is moving, breaking off abruptly with the childrenʼs sighting of the “man in the spence”, the ghost of Maryʼs father, and the youngest boyʼs tears—events that Ruskin slightly, and perhaps significantly, alters from the novel.

One other association may be noted, which returns the dating to early 1829, when Ruskin certainly fair‐copied books 3–4, and probably composed at least some portion of them. It is striking that Margaret expressed admiration of her son equally for writing a “novel” and for making sermon notes (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 185). Margaret did not necessarily consider these incompatible pursuits, as did some evangelicals, but she might have encouraged Ruskinʼs reading of The Monastery, owing to her opposition to Cathotic Emancipation, being debated at the time (see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 177). Scottʼs novel makes heroes of the Reformers and satirizes monastic failings, although Ruskinʼs poem largely neglects these themes.

div.head: Textual Note
div.p: The copytext is taken from MS III. One peculiarity of punctuation, especially in the first two books, is the frequent use of a colon, which seems to indicate a pause, as does the two‐point ellipsis in “Eudosia” (no. 27). (In fact, that strange mark in “Eudosia” may be a colon turned on its side.) Perpetually inventive, in “The Monastery”, Ruskin has come up with yet another mark of his own, the upside‐down semicolon, or comma above a period. I cannot distinguish a consistent function for this mark much different from that of Ruskinʼs colon, so, where it appears, I have put a colon in square brackets.
With book 3, the punctuation becomes less idiosyncratic. The MS IA draft is entirely unpunctuated.
